title: [cxx-interop][docs] Update getting started guide
body:
* Do not use `Cxx` as a user module name, since we now ship a built-in module called `Cxx`.
* Describe creating an Xcode target that builds the C++ module.
* Do not provide libc++ include paths manually to the Swift compiler, Swift should detect the C++ stdlib automatically.

title: [libSyntax] Fix function parameter parsing issue
body:
In libSyntax, `isolated` and `_const` are modelled as optional identifiers in the `FunctionParameter`, same as `firstName` and `secondName`. If the function parameter doesn't contain `isolated` or `_const`, the syntax context tries to form the `isolated` token from the first name.

For example, `func foo(myName: Int)` gets parsed as having a parameter
```
Attributes: <null>
IsolatedToken: `myName`
ConstToken: <null>
FirstName: <null>
SecondName: <null>
Colon: `:`
Type: `Int`
Ellipsis: <null>
DefaultArgument: <null>
TrailingComma: <null>
```

To disambiguate, explicitly record null nodes for the attribute list, `isolated` and `_const` token. All of this is a little hacky but because the C++ libSyntax parser will be gone at some point anyway, it shouldn't be too bad.

title: [Threading] Always round up when converting std::chrono::durations.
body:
We were inadvertently rounding down, which was fine almost 100% of the time, but on Windows where the timer resolution is only 1ms, it made the test _very slightly_ flaky because we were asking to wait for 9ms rather than 10ms, then checking we'd waited at least 10ms.

We should explicitly round up, for that reason.

rdar://100236038

title: [SILGen] Cleanup profiler handling
body:
- Use `SILDeclRef::hasUserWrittenCode` in `shouldProfile`, which subsumes existing logic and avoids emitting coverage maps for property wrapper backing initializers without user code (rdar://99931619).
- Stop forcing emission of functions for profiling, as we should now always SILGen functions with user-written code.
- Remove `setUpForProfiling`, instead creating the SILProfilers when we emit the function definitions. This matches what we do for other SILDeclRefs.

Also noticed that `SILDeclRef::isAnyThunk` is an exact copy of `SILDeclRef::isThunk`, and can be dropped.

title: Gardening: Migrate CHANGELOG.md to GitHub issues
Gardening: Migrate compiler sources to GitHub issues
body: I am intentionally violating the 80 char limit in a lot of places here. The idea is for `TODO` and `FIXME` to show up nicely in search results, context and all, no truncation. Doesn’t look too bad with line wrapping enabled. Also, perhaps unfortunately, Xcode doesn’t pick up on `TODO(...):` or `FIXME(...):`. Thoughts?

title: Add code owners for the parser
body: This will allow @ahoppen @bnbarham @CodaFi @DougGregor and @rintaro to be notified when changes are made to the parser to make sure corresponding changes are also done in the new parser, implemented inside the swift-syntax repo.

title: [Cxx-Interop] Cast Operators
body: Pushing to get some feedback.

title: [Demangler] Fix isThunkSymbol() to handle continuations.
body:
`isThunkSymbol()` was returning false for await resume and suspend resume thunks because the `Node` tree for those has an `AsyncAwaitResumePartialFunction` and/or `AsyncSuspendResumePartialFunction` as the first child of the top level `Global`, with the actual thunk in the _second_ child location.

rdar://100424460

title: Allow existential opening for parameters of optional type.
Sema: Accept `if #_hasSymbol()` conditions in closure contexts
body:
This is a follow up to https://github.com/apple/swift/pull/61148 that adds support for `if #_hasSymbol()` in closure contexts.

Resolves rdar://100129165

title: [5.7][android] Update to LTS NDK 25b (#60938)
body:
__Explanation:__ Make it so that the Swift build detects the clang shipping in the Android NDK, rather than having to manually update `SWIFT_ANDROID_NDK_CLANG_VERSION` every time, by extracting the versioned resource directory from the NDK using `file(GLOB)`.

__Scope:__ Only affects cross-compiling for Android with the NDK

__SR Issue:__ None

__Risk:__ Essentially none, since it only affects Android

__Testing:__ This patch got trunk compiling on the community Android CI again with the latest NDK 25b.

__Reviewer:__ @DougGregor

This pull will keep 5.7 patch releases compiling with future NDK releases, rather than having to [manually patch this repo with the new clang version each time](https://github.com/buttaface/swift-android-sdk/commit/e16bd2464fe944faee21b2f579b54006c0c531bc#diff-2d60757a966dd211063b699be169295db694f29a37d6dc72b0ff9146f57f3d4cR10). Since this pull is so low-risk, I thought it is worth getting in to 5.7.

title: [android][test] Tweaks to get the new failing C++ Interop tests working
body:
@drodriguez, let me know what you think: haven't tested the two failing tests that use `swift-ide-test` with this pull, but confirmed with a prebuilt toolchain snapshot that the last clang change gets the new `SwiftToCxx` tests working. Four of the five tests failing on the Android CI pass natively on Android, so I only disabled the one `memory-layout-silgen.swift` that fails both when cross-compiling with the NDK and natively compiling in the Termux app.

If you can try this out with an Android cross-compilation build you have lying around and let me know what you think, that'd be great, as I almost never build the Swift compiler on linux these days.

title: update-checkout: Do not update repository if not listed in the given branch-scheme
body: Consider two branch-schemes, where the second is a subset of the first. Suppose repositories have been cloned using the first branch scheme. Previously, a successive update using the second branch-scheme would cause update-checkout to fail in an attempt to query the branch-scheme about the target branch for a repository it does not map, even though the update, given no further errors, can be considered successful.

title: [Concurrency] Update documentation
body:
Documentation fixes:

* `PartialAsyncTask` → `UnownedJob`
* "partial tasks" → "jobs"

title: [docs] add a roadmap for Swift -> C++ interoperability
body:
This is a draft Swift and C++ interoperability roadmap document that describes how Swift APIs are going to interoperate with C++.

Rendered markdown is here:
https://github.com/hyp/swift/blob/eng/re-road/docs/CppInteroperability/SwiftToCppInteroperabilityRoadmap.md

title: Factor "maybeWrapInExistential" into builders
body: When decoding mangled names into types, a type may be optionally wrapped in an existential depending on the context (for example, if a protocol appears in a function signature's requirement it's only the protocol type, but if it appears as a type of a variable, it's an existential). This patch centralizes the logic of whether a type should be wrapped in an existential in a new "maybeWrapInExistential" in the builders.

title: Backdeploy task_wait_future fix to Swift 5.6
body:
This PR pulls in enough of the Swift 5.6 standard library to build and run `task_future_wait` and `task_future_wait_throwing` via the backdeploy library, and applies the fix in ef80a315f810419e8278af2aac1bf2bcb8fb0011 (https://github.com/apple/swift/pull/59377).

I've broken the patch into a couple pieces.
 - The first two commits pull in the original swift 5.6 stdlib and shouldn't be too exciting, it's mostly just copy-paste.
 - The third commit causes the linker to implicitly import the C++ stdlib when linking a binary that uses the 5.6 backdeploy library. Without this, folks would need to explicitly pass `-lc++` to their swiftc invocations.
 - The fourth commit is where the fix is actually applied. Note that the `AsyncTask::PrivateStorage::_status()` method didn't exist in 5.6, so I used what appears to be the equivalent `AsyncTask::PrivateStorage::Status` object.

I've checked that this runs by running `build/Ninja-ReleaseAssert/swift-macosx-arm64/bin/swiftc -sdk $(xcrun --show-sdk-path -sdk macosx) -runtime-compatibility-version 5.6 test.swift`. 

test.swift contains:
```swift
func fifteen() async -> Int {
    return 15
}

func twelve() async throws -> Int {
    return 12
}

async let Fifteen = fifteen()
async let Twelve = twelve()
print(await Fifteen)
print(try await Twelve)
```

rdar://95132657

title: [SourceKit] add qualified types in type requests
body:
This adds the fully qualified type to the response of expression and variable type requests in SourceKit.

The qualified type can be accessed through the `<key.expression_qualified_type>` and `<key.variable_qualified_type>` keys in the response of the expression and variable type requests.

title: [cxx-interop] A few fixes for how we handle class templates specialization.
body:
This should mostly be a NFC.

* Don't call `ClassTemplateDecl::specializations` to prevent modularization issues.
* Improve compile time (by not loading as many specializations and lowering the threashold).
* Lazily emit un-imported class template errors.
* Remove isSpecializationDepthGreaterThan hack.

title: [DNM] IRGen: Pass the elementType of pointers through to operations
body:
In preparation for moving to llvm's opaque pointer representation replace getPointerElementType and CreateCall/CreateLoad/Store uses that dependent on the address operand's pointer element type.

This means an `Address` carries the element type and we use `FunctionPointer` in more places or read the function type off the `llvm::Function`.

title: Adds sleep(for:) to clock
body:
This adds a duration-based `sleep(for:)` method to `Clock` as an alternative to using the instant-based `sleep(until:)` method.

Evolution proposal coming next, and [here's](https://forums.swift.org/t/pitch-clock-sleep-for/60376) a forum discussion.

title: [NFC] Emit descriptive string constant names
body:
This PR modifies `getAddrOfGlobalString()` to generate constants whose names reflect their actual contents. Rather than having generic names like `@.str`, `@.str.1`, etc., they now have names like `@".str.11.Hello World"`. This means that when you're FileChecking IR, you can hardcode the expected constant name at the use site and assume that it has the desired contents, rather than matching the constant declaration, capturing the name, and using the captured name in a separate line matching the use site.

This PR includes a description of this format in docs/Testing.md and a new test ensuring that the compiler correctly generates the desired format, but because these string constants are private anyway, it should have no effect on the code size or other behavior of linked binaries.

title: [DNM][c++ interop] Showcase SILGen crash when successor() is used

title: Issue-60730: Addressing the situation where we were saying that (any …
body:
…P)? does not conform to P, instead we should offer the Force Optional error messaging

<!-- What's in this pull request? -->
Addressing Issue-60730 (https://github.com/apple/swift/issues/60730). In this scenario, we were showing the error message `error: Argument type '(any P)?' does not conform to expected type 'P'` to the user. In the case outlined in the issue, a more informative message would be displayed if we applied the `ForceOptional` fix, which is exactly what this PR does.

Resolves: https://github.com/apple/swift/issues/60730
